(iii) Metamorphism. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Geography
fields.text:
(a) (i) Name two settlement patterns. (2 marks)
(ii) Explain four physical factors that influence settlement. (8 marks)
(b) (i) Explain how the following factors have led to the growth of Thika:
- Location. (2 marks)
- Transport. (2 marks)
- Land. (2 marks)
(ii) Apart from being a transport and communication centre, give three other functions of Thika town. (3 marks)
(c) Explain three positive effects of urbanisation to a country. (6 marks)

fields.subject: Geography
fields.text:
(a) Identify three sources of renewable energy. (3 marks)
(b) (i) Name three main Hydro Electric Power stations along the River Tana. (3 marks)
(ii) Apart from providing electric power, state four other benefits of the dams along the River Tana. (4 marks)
(iii) Identify two problems that affect the production of power from the stations along River Tana. (2 marks)
(c) Explain four measures the Government of Kenya has taken to conserve energy. (8 marks)
(d) Some students carried out a field study on sources of energy by sampling households around their school.
(i) Identify two sampling techniques the students may have used during the study. (2 marks)
(ii) Give three advantages of sampling the household for the study. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Geography
fields.text:
(a) (i) What is visible trade? (2 marks)
(ii) List three major imports to Kenya from Japan. (3 marks)
(b) Explain four factors that influence internal trade in Kenya. (8 marks)
(c) State four ways in which trade is of significance to Kenya. (4 marks)
(d) Explain four benefits which member states of ECOWAS derive from the formation of the trading bloc. (8 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Identify one disadvantage of using anthropology as a source of information in History and Government.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Identify two communities in Kenya which belong to the Western Bantu group.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
State two similarities in the political organisation of the Ameru and Abaluhya of Kenya during the 19th Century.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Give one economic duty of a Kenyan citizen.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Identify two foreign powers that took control of the Kenyan Coast during the 16th Century.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Which factor influenced Seyyid Said to develop agriculture in Zanzibar during the 16th Century?
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
State two ways through which the construction of the Uganda railway facilitated the colonisation of Kenya.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
State the meaning of "Direct democracy".
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Give two Education Commissions appointed by the Government of Kenya to review the Education System since independence.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Identify one reason why the government may limit one's freedom of expression in Kenya.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
State two features of African farming in Kenya during the colonial period.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
What was the main reason why the second Lancaster House Conference was held in 1962?
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
State one way through which the Harambee spirit among Kenyans promotes national unity.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Give two negative effects of over reliance on foreign aid for the country.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Give one symbol of national unity in Kenya.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Who is the administrative head of Parliament in Kenya?
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
Identify the police department responsible for maintaining law and order.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Identify five causes of the Nandi resistance against British invasion in Kenya.
(5 marks)
(b) Explain five results of the Maasai collaboration with the British in the early 20th Century.
(10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Outline three reasons of Somali resistance against the British rule in Kenya in the 19th Century.
(3 marks)
(b) Describe six negative effects of British colonial rule on the people of Kenya.
(12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Outline five grievances expressed by the Kikuyu Central Association and presented by Jomo Kenyatta to the Colonial Secretary in 1929.
(5 marks)
(b) Explain the role played by Thomas Joseph Mboya in the development of trade union movement in Kenya.
(10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) State three challenges that hinder government effort to eradicate illiteracy in Kenya.
(3 marks)
(b) Describe six factors that have influenced industrialisation in Kenya since independence.
(12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Identify five circumstances that can make a registered voter be denied the right to vote in Kenya.
(5 marks)
(b) Describe the rights of an accused person in a court of law during trial in Kenya.
(10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Name five types of courts in Kenya.
(5 marks)
(b) Explain the importance of separation of powers between the Legislature, Executive and Judiciary in Kenya.
(10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Give the three categories of the Kenya Defence Forces.
(3 marks)
(b) Explain six challenges encountered by the Kenya Police Service in the course of discharging their duties.
(12 marks)

fields.subject: IRE
fields.text:
(a) With reference to Surah An-Nur, describe the prescribed punishment for zina and for qadhaf (slander). (8 marks)
(b) State the teachings of the last two verses of Surah Al-Baqarah (Q. 2:285-286). (12 marks)

fields.subject: IRE
fields.text:
(a) Discuss the role played by angel Jibril in the revelation of the Qur'an. (6 marks)
(b) Explain the importance of the Qur'an to a Muslim. (8 marks)
(c) Why is the Qur'an considered a miracle by Muslims. (6 marks)

fields.subject: IRE
fields.text:
(a) State the etiquettes that should be observed when reading the Qur'an. (10 marks)
(b) State the methods used by the Prophet (P.b.u.h.) to teach his Sunnah and Hadith. (10 marks)

fields.subject: IRE
fields.text:
(a) Identify four obligatory acts in the performance of wudhu. (4 marks)
(b) Explain four effects of Swalat on a Muslim. (8 marks)
(c) Differentiate between Fardh and Sunnah Saum. (8 marks)

fields.subject: IRE
fields.text:
(a) Give five differences between Sharia and secular law. (10 marks)
(b) Mention the acts that nullify Saum. (10 marks)

fields.subject: IRE
fields.text:
(a) Mention five angels and the duties that each perform. (5 marks)
(b) Explain five ways in which the Prophets of Allah facilitated divine guidance. (10 marks)
(c) Give five characteristics of angels of Allah. (5 marks)

fields.subject: Kiswahili
fields.text:
UFAHAMU: (Alama 15)
Soma kifungu kifuatacho kisha ujibu maswali.
Ulimwengu unatakiwa kuzua mbinu za kulitatua tatizo la ufukara ambao ni kikwazo kikuu cha juhudi za maendeleo. Ufukara unayakabili mataifa mengi yanayoendelea na kuyatosa kwenye shida nyingi huku mataifa ya magharibi yakizidi kupiga hatua kubwa za kimaendeleo. Tofauti iliyopo kati ya mataifa yanayoendelea na yaliyoendelea inaendelea kuongezeka kila siku. Miongoni mwa sababu zinazochangia katika ufukara huu ni pamoja na ufisadi, uongozi mbaya, turathi za kikoloni na uchumi unaotegemea kilimo ambacho hutegemea mvua isiyoweza kutabirika. Vilevile, mataifa yanayoendelea yana idadi kubwa ya watu inayoupiku uwezo wa mataifa husika. Pamoja na haya, mataifa haya hayana uwezo wa kuwakomboa raia wake kutoka katika lindi la umaskini huu unaokithiri. Ukosefu wa elimu na nafasi adimu za kazi huchangia pia katika tatizo hili. Ni wazi kuwa ufukara una athari hasi kote ulimwenguni. Aghalabu, ufukara huchipuza matendo mabaya. Ni rahisi kuwashawishi wananchi maskini kushiriki katika uhalifu ili kujinasua kutoka kwenye lindi la kimaskini. Udhaifu huu huweza kuzaa mbegu ya kuatika maovu ya kila aina ukiwemo ugaidi. Mataifa yaliyoendelea yanatakiwa kuyaburai madeni yanayoyadai mataifa yanayaoendelea kama njia moja ya kupambana na ufukara. Mataifa haya maskini hutumia asilimia kubwa ya mapato ya kitaifa kuyalipia madeni haya. Hali hii imeyafanya mataifa haya kushindwa kujikwamua kutoka kwenye minyororo ya ufukara. Njia nyingine ya kuyasaidia mataifa haya ni kukubali kutoa ruzuku za kimaendeleo badala ya mikopo kwa nchi husika. Mataifa yanayoendelea nayo yanatakiwa kuchukua hatua katika kuwanusuru raia wake kutoka kwenye dhiki hii. Ni sharti yaibuke na mikakati kabambe ya kupambana na ufukara. Itakuwa na faida kubwa iwapo mataifa haya yataunda sera zinazotambua ufukara kama tatizo kuu linalozikabili na kuweka mikakati ya kuwaokoa raia wake kutoka kwenye tatizo hili. Pamoja na mikakati hii ni kuzalisha nafasi za kazi, kuimarisha miundo msingi, kuendeleza elimu inayolenga kutatua matatizo maalumu katika jamii na kupanua viwanda. Kuna pia haja ya viongozi kuwa waangalifu ili mfumo wa soko huru ambao unaendelezwa na mataifa yaliyondelea usiishie kuwa chanzo cha kufa kwa viwanda asilia. Maamuzi yote ya sera za kiuchumi sharti yauzingatie uhalisia wa maisha ya raia wa mataifa haya.
(a)
Eleza athari za madeni kwa nchi zinazoendelea.
(alama 2)
(b)
Kwa nini umaskini unatawala mataifa yanayoendelea?
(alama 4)
(c)
Mwandishi anatoa mapendekezo yapi kwa mataifa yanayoendelea katika kutatua tatizo la ufukakra?
(alama 4)
(d)
Mfumo wa siko huru una mathara gani kwa mataifa yanayoendelea?
(alama 2)
(e) Taja visawe vya maneno yafuatayo kama yalivyotumika katika kifungu.
(i)
turathi za kikoloni
(ii)
kuatika
(iii)
kuyaburai
(alama 3)
MUHTASARI: (Alama 15)
Soma kifungu kifuatacho kisha ujibu maswali.
Taifa huundwa na watu wanaoishi katika nchi moja na wanaojitambua kisiasa kama watu walio na mwelekeo, maono na hatima sawa. Utaifa hujengwa kwenye misingi ya mapenzi kwa nchi. Utambuzi wa cheo, eneo, hadhi, rangi na hata makabila wanakotoka raia wa taifa moja si chanzo cha kuwatanganisha. Nchi moja huweza kuundwa na watu walio na tofauti chungu nzima zikiwemo tofauti za kikabila, kitabaka na kimawazo. Hata hivyo, watu hawa huwa na kitu mfano wa gundi kinachowaunganisha na kuwafanya kuonea fahari nchi yao. Watu hao huwa na falsafa na imani sawa kama taifa inayoashiriwa hasa na wimbo wa taifa. Hata hivyo haya yote hayawezi kuwafikia katika kiwango cha kuunda taifa. Uzalendo ndio mhimili mkuu wa utaifa. Uzalendo ni mapenzi aliyo nayo mtu kwa nchi yake. Mapenzi haya humwongoza mtu katika mawazo yake, itikadi yake, matendo yake, matamanio yake na mkabala wake kuhusu nchi na hatima ya nchi yake. Mzalendo hawezi kushiriki katika matendo yanayoweza kuiletea nchi yake maangamizo kwa vyovyote vile. Mzalendo huongozwa na mwenge wa wema. Mzalendo hawezi kushiriki kwenye shughuli zozote zinazohujumu mshikamano wa kitaifa. Yeye hatawaliwi na ubinafsi wa kutaka kufaidi nafsi yake na ya jamii yake finyu. Matendo yake yote huongozwa na ari ya kuiboresha nchi yake. Anayeipenda nchi yake hujiepusha na ulafi wa kujilimbikizia mali. Yuko radhi kuhasirika mradi taifa lake linufaike. Utaifa ni mche aali unaopaliliwa kwa uzalendo, kuepuka uchu wa nafsi na taasubi hasi zikuwepo za kikabila na ubinafsi. Hali hii inapofikiwa, hatima ya taifa na mustakabali wa raia wake huwa wenye matumaini makubwa.
(a)
Kwa maneno 40-50 dondoa sifa kuu za utaifa.
(alama 6, 1 ya mtiririko)
Matayarisho
Nakala safi
(b)
Ni nini misingi ya kutathmini mzalendo? (maneno 60-70)
(alama 9, 1 ya mtiririko)
Matayarisho
Nakala safi
MATUMIZI YA LUGHA: (alama 40)
(a)
Tumia nomino yoyote katika ngeli ya I - I kutunga sentensi.
(alama 1)
(b)
(i)
Nini maana ya silabi.
(ii)
Tunga neno lenye muundo huu wa silabi: Irabu + konsonanti + konsonanti + irabu.
(alama 2)
(c)
Tunga sentensi hii upya kwa kufuata maagizo:
Wasichana wanaingia darasani kwa haraka. (Andika kinyume chake).
(alama 2)
(d)
Tambua kiambishi awali na tamati kati neno:
Alalaye
(alama 2)
(e)
Ainisha vivumishi katika sentensi hii.
Mzee mwenyewe ni mkongwe na amepewa zawadi kwa kuwa shamba lake lilitoa mazao mengi.
(alama 4)
(f)
Askari wasipopiga doria wala kushirikiana na raia hawatakuwa wametuhakikishia usalama. (yakinisha sentensi hii)
(alama 2)
(g)
"Shughuli yetu itakamilika kesho", mama alimwambia mwanaye Juma (Andika katika usemi wa taarifa).
(alama 2)
(h)
Changamua sentensi ifuatayo kwa kielelezo cha matawi.
Mpira ulichezwa tulipokuwa tukipika.
(alama 3)
(i)
Dhihirisha matumizi matatu tofauti ya kimaana yatakayotokea kitenzi "ona" kikinyambuliwa katika kirai hiki "ona ndoto".
(alama 3)
(j)
Eleza matumizi ya hali za "ka" na "hu" katika sentensi zifuatazo:
(i)
Balozi huja hapa kila mara.
(alama 1)
(ii)
Mpishi alipika, akapakuwa na akagawa chakula.
(alama 1)
(k)
Eleza maana mbili zinazojitokeza katika sentensi:
Tuliitwa na baba.
(alama 2)
(l)
Akifisha:
Shangazi alimwambia mwanawe njoo nikupeleke kwenu jioni motto aliuliza kwetu wapi?
(alama 4)
(m)
Eleza matumizi mawili ya kiambishi-ji-
(alama 2)
(n)
Tunga sentensi hii upya kwa kutumia visawe vya maneno yaliyopigwa mstari.
Kiambaza kilimuumiza ghulamu alipokuwa akipanda.
(alama 3)
(o)
Tumia kitenzi "Fa" katika sentensi kuonyesha mazoea.
(alama 2)
(p)
Ainisha vibusishi katika sentensi ifuatayo:
Babu alifika mapema kuliko wote halafu akaondoka.
(alama 2)
(q)
Tumia kitenzi "tafakari" kama nomino katika sentensi.
(alama 1)
(r)
Andika upya sentensi ifuatayo kwa kutumia viwakilishi badala ya nomino zilizopigwa mstari. Mwanamziki ataembelea mji.
(alama 1)
ISIMUJAMII (Alama 10)
Kwa kutoa mifano maridhawa, eleza kaida zozote tano ambazo matumizi ya lugha hutegemea katika jamii.
(Alama 10)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Without using a calculator evaluate: \(\frac{-2(5+3)-9+3+5}{-3 \times 5 + -2 \times 4}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Simplify \(\frac{p^2 + 2p - 15}{p^2 - 16} \times \frac{p + 4}{p + 5}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: A cylindrical water tank has an internal diameter of 2.8 m. The thickness of the material making the container is 5 mm. If the container has 8 litres of water, calculate the internal height above the water level. (4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: The figure below shows a net of a solid (measurements are in centimetres). Below is a part of the sketch of the solid whose net is shown above. Complete the sketch of the solid, showing the hidden edges with broken lines. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Given that \(\overrightarrow{OA} = 2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = 3\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j}\), find the magnitude of \(\overrightarrow{AB}\) to one decimal place. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: A bus travelling at an average speed of 63 km/h left a station at 8:15 a.m. A car later left the same station at 9:00 a.m. and travelled in the same direction at an average speed of 108 km/h. Calculate the time the car caught up with the bus. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Given that \(x\) is an acute angle and \(\cos x = \frac{3\sqrt{5}}{5}\), find, without using mathematical tables or a calculator, \(\tan (90^\circ - x)\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Without using mathematical tables or a calculator, evaluate \(27^{\frac{3}{4}} \times \left(\frac{81}{16}\right)^{\frac{1}{4}}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: 9. A minor arc of a circle subtends an angle of 105° at the centre of the circle. If the radius of the circle is 8.4 cm, find the length of the major arc. (Take \(\pi = \frac{22}{7}\)). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: The gradient of the tangent to the curve \(y = ax^2 + bx\) at the point (1, 1) is -5. Calculate the values of \(a\) and \(b\). (4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: A line with gradient of -3 passes through the points (3, k) and (k, 8). Find the value of \(k\) and hence express the equation of the line in the form \(ax + by = c\), where \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are constants. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Points K, L, and M are on a straight line such that KL:LM = 2:3. The coordinates of L are (2, 3) and those of M are (7, -2). Find the coordinates of K. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In this question, mathematical tables should not be used. A Kenyan bank buys and sells foreign currencies as shown below:
Buying (in Kenya Shillings) Selling (in Kenya Shillings)
1 US Dollar 84.15 84.25
1 Sterling Pound 124.27 124.77
A tourist arrived in Kenya with 5000 US Dollars and changed all the dollars to Kenya Shillings at the bank. He spent Ksh 256,750 and changed the remaining Kenya Shillings to Sterling Pounds. Calculate the amount in Sterling Pounds he received. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The number of goats in a farm was recorded on 14 consecutive days. The number of goats born each day was recorded as follows: 22, 26, 15, 19, 20, 16, 27, 15, 19, 22, 21, 20, 22, and 28. Determine:
(a) The mode. (1 mark)
(b) The median. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Two towns P and Q are 400 km apart. The bearing of Q from P is 330°. The bearing of M from K is 220°. Calculate the bearing of M from L. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Given that \(\log 4 = 0.6021\) and \(\log 6 = 0.7782\), without using mathematical tables or a calculator, evaluate \(\log 0.096\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) Solve the equation \(\frac{x + 3}{24} = \frac{1}{x - 2}\). (4 marks)
(b) The length of a floor of a rectangular hall is 9 m more than its width. The area of the floor is 136 m².
(i) Calculate the width of the floor. (4 marks)
(ii) A rectangular carpet is placed on the floor leaving an area of 64 m². If the length of the carpet is twice its width, determine the width of the carpet. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Three business partners: Asha, Nangila, and Cherop contributed Ksh 60,000, Ksh 85,000, and Ksh 105,000 respectively. They agreed to put 25% of the profit back into business each year. They also agreed to put aside 40% of the remaining profit for running expenses, and to share the rest in the ratio of their contributions.
(a) At the end of the first year, the business made a profit of Ksh 135,000. Calculate the amount of money Nangila received. (5 marks)
(b) Given that the gross profit at the end of the second year increased in the ratio 10:9, calculate Nangila’s share of the profit at the end of the second year. (5 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The frequency table below shows the daily wages paid to casual workers by a certain company.
Wages in Shillings 100-150 150-200 200-300 300-400 400-600
Frequency 10 16 24 30 20
(a) Calculate the mean wage. (3 marks)
(b) Draw a histogram, showing where the median wage lies. (4 marks)
(c) Using the histogram, determine the number of workers who earn Sh 450 or less per day. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In the diagram below, the coordinates of points A and B are (1, 6) and (15, 6) respectively. Point N is on OB such that 3ON = 2OB. Line OA is produced to L such that OA = AL.
(a) Find vector LN. (3 marks)
(b) Given that a point M is on LN such that LM:MN = 3:4, find the coordinates of M. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) The ratio of Juma’s and Akinyi’s earnings was 5:3. Juma’s earnings rose to Ksh 8,400 after an increase of 12%. Calculate the percentage increase in Akinyi’s earnings given that the sum of their new earnings was Ksh 14,100. (6 marks)
(b) Juma and Akinyi contributed all the new earnings to buy maize. The maize was then sold at Ksh 1,762.50 per bag. The two shared all the money from the sales of the maize in the ratio of their contributions. Calculate the amount that Akinyi got. (4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Using a pair of compasses and ruler only, construct:
(a) (i) Triangle ABC in which AB = 5 cm, \(\angle BAC = 30^\circ\), and \(\angle ABC = 105^\circ\). (3 marks)
(a) (ii) A circle that passes through the vertices A, B, and C. (3 marks)
(a) (iii) The height of triangle ABC with AB as the base. Measure the height. (2 marks)
(b) Determine the area of the circle that lies outside the triangle correct to 2 decimal places. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The equation of a curve is \(y = 2x^3 + 3x^2\).
(a) Find:
(i) The \(x\)-intercept of the curve. (2 marks)
(ii) The \(y\)-intercept of the curve. (1 mark)
(b) (i) Determine the stationary points of the curve. (3 marks)
(b) (ii) For each point in (b)(i) above, determine whether it is a maximum or a minimum. (2 marks)
(c) Sketch the curve. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) On the grid provided, draw a graph of the function \(y = \frac{1}{2}x^2 - x + 3\) for \(0 \leq x \leq 6\). (3 marks)
(b) Calculate the mid-ordinates for five strips between \(x = 1\) and \(x = 6\), and hence use the mid-ordinate rule to approximate the area under the curve between \(x = 1\), \(x = 6\), and the \(x\)-axis. (3 marks)
(c) Assuming that the area determined by integration to be the actual area, calculate the percentage error in using the mid-ordinate rule. (4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Simplify \(\frac{3x - 6}{x^2 - 4} \div \frac{x - 2}{x + 2}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Solve the equation \(2x^2 - 3x - 5 = 0\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: In a quadrilateral PQRS, PQ = QR, angle PQR = 70^\circ, and angle QPS = 40^\circ. Calculate angle QRS. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Make \(s\) the subject of the formula \(w = \frac{s}{\sqrt{t}}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: A number \(n\) is such that when it is divided by 3, 7, or 11, the remainder is always one. Find the smallest value of \(n\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: The volume of a cylinder is \(200 \text{ cm}^3\). If the radius of its base is \(r \text{ cm}\), express the height \(h \text{ cm}\) of the cylinder in terms of \(r\) and find the height when \(r = 5 \text{ cm}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: The masses in kilograms of 20 bags of maize were: 90, 94, 96, 98, 99, 102, 103, 91, 102, 99, 105, 94, 99, 90, 94, 99, 98, 96, 102 and 105. Using an assumed mean of 96 kg, calculate the mean mass, in kilograms, of a bag of maize. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The first term of an arithmetic sequence is 7 and the common difference is 3.
(a) List the first six terms of the sequence. (1 mark)
(b) Determine the sum of the first 50 terms of the sequence. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A bag contains 2 white balls and 3 black balls. A second bag contains 3 white balls and 2 black balls. The balls are identical except for the colours. Two balls are drawn at random, one after the other from the first bag without replacement. Calculate the probability that:
(a) Both balls are white. (2 marks)
(b) The balls are of different colours. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: A circle whose centre is at point \((-2, 3)\) has a radius of 5 units. Calculate the length, correct to one decimal place, of a chord that subtends an angle of 90^\circ at the centre of the same circle. (4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Given that \(\mathbf{q} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} + 3 \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\) is a unit vector, find \(\mathbf{q}\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) Expand the expression \((1 + \frac{x}{2})^5\) in ascending powers of \(x\), leaving the coefficients as fractions in their simplest form. (2 marks)
(b) Use the first three terms of the expansion in (a) above to estimate the value of \((1.1)^5\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: A circle whose equation is \((x - 1)^2 + (y + k)^2 = 10\) passes through the point \((2, 5)\). Find the value of \(k\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Water and milk are mixed such that the volume of water to that of milk is 4:1. Taking the density of water as \(1 \text{ g/cm}^3\) and that of milk as \(1.2 \text{ g/cm}^3\), find the density of the mixture. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: Find, in radians, the values of \(x\) in the interval \(0^\circ \leq x \leq 2\pi\) for which \(2 \cos^2 x - \sin x = 1\). (Leave the answer in terms of \(\pi\)). (4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: The gradient of a curve at any point \((x, y)\) is \(2x - 3\). Given that the curve passes through point \((2, 5)\), find the equation of the curve. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The position vectors of points \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) are \(\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix}\), \(\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ -1 \end{pmatrix}\), and \(\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} -1 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix}\) respectively.
(a) Find the coordinates of point \(D\) such that \(\overrightarrow{AB} = \overrightarrow{CD}\). (3 marks)
(b) Find the magnitude of \(\overrightarrow{BC}\), correct to one decimal place. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In the figure below, \(P\), \(Q\), \(R\), and \(S\) are points on the circle with centre \(O\). \(PRT\) and \(USTV\) are straight lines. Line \(USTV\) is a tangent to the circle at \(S\), \(\angle RST = 50^\circ\), and \(\angle RTV = 150^\circ\).
(a) Calculate the size of:
(i) \(\angle QRS\). (2 marks)
(ii) \(\angle USP\). (2 marks)
(b) Given that \(RT = TS\), calculate \(\angle RTP\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure ABCDEF below represents a roof of a house.
(a) Calculate, correct to one decimal place, the area of the triangle \(ABC\). (3 marks)
(b) Calculate the angle between:
(i) The line \(AE\) and the plane \(ABCD\), correct to 1 decimal place. (2 marks)
(ii) The planes \(ABFE\) and \(DCFE\), correct to 1 decimal place. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A water vendor has a tank of capacity 18,000 litres. The tank is being filled with water from two pipes \(A\) and \(B\) which are closed immediately when the tank is full. Water flows at the rate of 150,000 cm³/minute through pipe \(A\) and 120,000 cm³/minute through pipe \(B\).
(a) If the tank is empty and the two pipes are opened at the same time:
(i) Calculate the time it takes to fill the tank. (3 marks)
(ii) On a given day, the vendor opened pipe \(A\) for 40 minutes before opening pipe \(B\). Calculate the total time taken to fill the tank on that day. (4 marks)
(b) The vendor supplied a total of 542 jerrycans, each containing 25 litres of water, on that day. If the water that remained in the tank was 6,000 litres, calculate, in litres, the amount of water that was wasted. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A tourist took 1 hour 20 minutes to travel by an aircraft from town \(T (3^\circ S, 35^\circ E)\) to town \(U (9^\circ N, 35^\circ E)\). (Take the radius of the earth to be 6,370 km and \(\pi = \frac{22}{7}\)).
(a) Find the average speed of the aircraft in km/h. (4 marks)
(b) If the aircraft flew back from \(U\) to \(T\) at the same speed, calculate the time taken, to the nearest minute. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The marks scored by 40 candidates in an examination are shown in the table below:
Marks 10-19 20-29 30-39 40-49 50-59 60-69 70-79
Frequency 2 4 6 12 10 4 2
(a) Calculate the mean mark, correct to 2 decimal places. (4 marks)
(b) Calculate the median mark, correct to 2 decimal places. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The vertices of a quadrilateral \(KLMN\) are \(K(-2, 4)\), \(L(6, 4)\), \(M(4, 0)\), and \(N(-4, 0)\). The quadrilateral is transformed to \(K'L'M'N'\) by a rotation of 90^\circ clockwise about the origin, followed by a reflection in the line \(y = x\).
(a) Find the coordinates of \(K'L'M'N'\). (3 marks)
(b) On the grid provided, draw the quadrilateral \(KLMN\) and its image \(K'L'M'N'\). (2 marks)
(c) (i) Describe fully the transformation which maps \(K'L'M'N'\) onto \(KLMN\). (2 marks)
(c) (ii) Determine the area of the image. (1 mark)
(d) Find a matrix which maps \(K'L'M'N'\) onto \(KLMN\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The first, fifth, and seventh terms of an arithmetic progression (A.P.) correspond to the first three consecutive terms of a decreasing Geometric Progression (G.P.). The first term of each progression is 64, the common difference of the A.P. is \(d\), and the common ratio of the G.P. is \(r\).
(a) (i) Write two equations involving \(d\) and \(r\). (2 marks)
(a) (ii) Find the values of \(d\) and \(r\). (4 marks)
(b) Find the sum of the first 10 terms of:
(i) The arithmetic progression (A.P.). (2 marks)
(ii) The Geometric Progression (G.P.). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
Harmonise the following Soprano Melody by adding Alto, Tenor and Bass. Choose appropriate chorals from I, II, IV, V and VI. Incorporate a passing tone in the top voice and two cadences.
(15 marks)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
African Music
(a)
(i) Identify three parts of an African Traditional lamellaphone, stating the role played by each part in sound production.
(3 marks)
(ii) Name one example of a lamellaphone from Kenya.
(½ mark)
(b) Explain three features of the African Traditional folk songs that make them best suited for oral transmission.
(4½ marks)
(c) Name two examples of each of the following instruments from Kenya.
(i) Side-blown flutes
(1 mark)
(ii) End-blown flutes
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
(a) Thomas Tallis
(i) Identify four types of works composed by Tallis.
(4 marks)
(b) Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
(i) State two factors that promoted Mozart's musical development in childhood.
(2 marks)
(ii) Name the work whose development and popularisation is fully attributed to Mozart.
(1 mark)
(iii) Give one example of each of the following works by Mozart:
I – Opera Buffa
(½ mark)
II – Opera Seria
(½ mark)
(iv) Outline three key features of 'style galant' favoured by Mozart.
(3 marks)
(c) Robert Schumann
(i) Schumann was famous for concentrating his energies on one form of music at a time. Identify the forms he mainly composed during the following periods:
I – Before 1840
(1 mark)
II – In 1840
(1 mark)
III – In 1841
(1 mark)
IV – In 1842
(1 mark)
(ii) State one feature of the opera ‘Genoveva’ (op.81) which makes it different from the traditional opera.
(1 mark)
(iii) Name two song cycles by Schumann.
(2 marks)
(d) Aaron Copland
(i) State three ways in which Copland contributed to the development of music during his time.
(3 marks)
(ii) State four references on Copland’s style of composition.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
Analysis of prescribed African music
(a) With reference to the performance in the recording, outline five features that contribute to the creation of the climax.
(5 marks)
(b) Describe the call-response style in the opening section of the performance.
(2 marks)
(c) State two ways in which the voice is cued in this performance.
(2 marks)
(d) Describe the mood of this performance.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
Analysis of prescribed western music
(a) With reference to specific bars. Identify the form of the opening section (Bar 1 to 24).
(2½ marks)
(b) Identify three ways through which a sudden contrast is created between bars 32–40 in relation to the previous section.
(3 marks)
(c) Outline the difference between bars ‘54–64’ and ‘88–96’.
(1 mark)
(d) Identify the choral progression from bar 96 to 104. Use bar numbers to illustrate your answer.
(2½ marks)
(e) State the name given to the type of LH accompaniment between bars 110 and 116.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
Analysis of unprepared work
(a) Identify the most prevalent articulation mark used in this music.
(½ mark)
(b) With reference to specific bar numbers, identify the general form of this music.
(2 marks)
(c)
(i) Which section of the music is presented in the Major mode? Refer to bar numbers for illustration.
(1 mark)
(ii) Name the melodic feature peculiar to the section in (i) above.
(1 mark)
(d) Describe the first chord in bar 3.
(1 mark)
(e) State the meaning of the term “vivace” as used in the music.
(½ mark)

fields.subject: Music
fields.text:
General Music Knowledge
(a) The melody below is written for Alto Saxophone in E flat. Rewrite it for clarinet in B flat to sound at the same pitch. Prefix the new key signature.
(5 marks)
(b) State four ways through which the harmonic effect is achieved during the group performance of a traditional African folk song.
(4 marks)
(c) Outline the meaning of the following terms as used in music.
(i) Embouchure
(1 mark)
(ii) Diction
(1 mark)
(iii) Producer
(1 mark)
(iv) Root
(1 mark)
(v) Signature tune
(1 mark)
(d) Explain why the actual performance of the “Trio Sonata” contradicts the scoring of this work.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: State what mechanics as a branch of physics deals with. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Explain how the rate at which a liquid evaporates from an open dish is estimated by determining the area of the patch. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Explain why the level of mercury in a mercury barometer is likely to fall when the barometer is tilted. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 2(a) and 2(b) show capillary tubes inserted in water and mercury respectively. It is observed that the level of water in a capillary tube rises while that of mercury falls. Explain this observation. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 3 shows a set-up used to investigate the variation of the extension of two metal rods of different materials. Use this information to answer questions 5(a) and 5(b).
(a) What property of metals could be tested using this set-up? (1 mark)
(b) Besides the length of the rods that is kept constant, state two other factors that should be kept constant for a fair test. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 5 shows an object placed in front of a convex mirror. Explain how the image is formed. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 6 shows parts A, B, and C of a glass tube. State with a reason the part of the tube in which the pressure will be lowest when air is blown through the tube from A towards C. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 7 shows two identical helical springs supporting a load of 30 N. Each spring extends by 2 cm. Determine the spring constant of each spring. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Explain how the two tubes in a double tube experiment can be separated by applying a temperature change. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 8 shows two cylinders of different cross-sectional areas connected with a tube. The cylinders contain an incompressible fluid. Explain how a force applied on the large piston is transmitted to the small piston. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: A body moving with uniform acceleration along a straight line covers 24 m in the 5th second and 36 m in the 7th second. Calculate the acceleration of the body. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Explain why a bucket full of water feels lighter when placed in water than in air. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: The graph in Figure 10 shows the velocity of a car in the first 8 seconds as it accelerates from rest along a straight line. Determine the distance travelled 3.0 seconds after the start. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Explain why it is advisable to use a pressure cooker for cooking at high altitudes. (2 marks)
(b) 500 g of a liquid at 20°C is heated until it all vaporizes at 100°C. Given that the specific heat capacity of the liquid is 2000 J/kgK, the specific latent heat of vaporization is 2.26 × 10^6 J/kg, and the specific heat capacity of the vapour is 2010 J/kgK, calculate:
(i) The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of the liquid to 100°C. (3 marks)
(ii) The amount of heat required to vaporize all the liquid at 100°C. (2 marks)
(iii) The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of the vapour to 120°C. (2 marks)
(iv) How much longer it will take to boil away all the water. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) State the meaning of the term ideal gas. (1 mark)
(b) Figure 11 shows a graph of pressure against the reciprocal of volume for a fixed mass of gas at constant temperature. Explain the relationship between the pressure \(P\), and the reciprocal of volume, \(\frac{1}{V}\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Define the term velocity ratio of a machine. (1 mark)
(b) Figure 12 shows part of a hydraulic press. The plunger is the piston where effort is applied. The ram piston is the one where the load is applied. The plunger has a cross-sectional area of 0.002 m² and the ram piston an area of 0.3 m².
(i) Given that a force of 100 N is applied on the plunger, determine the maximum load that can be lifted. (3 marks)
(ii) Calculate the efficiency of the machine. (2 marks)
(iii) Calculate the percentage of the work that goes to waste. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) When a bus goes round a bend at constant speed, state what physical quantity changes. (1 mark)
(b) State the purpose of banking roads at bends. (2 marks)
(c) A body of mass 0.5 kg is rotated in a vertical circle of radius 0.2 m at a constant speed using a string. The difference in the tensions in the string at the top and bottom of the circle is 9.8 N. Calculate the speed of the body. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 1 shows a ray of light incident on a mirror at an angle of \(45^\circ\). Another mirror is placed at an angle of \(45^\circ\) to the first one. Complete the diagram to show the path of the ray after reflection from the second mirror. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: An unmagnetized steel rod is clamped facing North-South direction and then hammered repeatedly. Explain why the rod becomes magnetized. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 2 shows a solenoid carrying an electric current. Sketch the magnetic field pattern inside and outside the solenoid. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 3 shows how the displacement of a point varies with time as a wave passes it. On the same diagram, draw a wave which passes the point with half the amplitude and twice the frequency of the one shown. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: State one cause of energy loss in a transformer and state how the loss is minimized. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 4 shows a converging lens placed in a ripple tank to reduce its depth. Complete the diagram to show the waves in both the shallow region and beyond the lens. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 5 shows the cross-section of a dry cell. Use the information on the figure to answer Question 7.
(a) Name the parts labelled A and B. (2 marks)
(b) State the use of the manganese (IV) oxide in the cell. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: The following is part of a radioactive series: \(^{232}_{90}\text{Th} \rightarrow ^{228}_{88}\text{Ra}\). Determine the values of \(a\) and \(b\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Draw a ray diagram to show how a ray of light may be totally internally reflected two times in an isosceles right-angled glass prism. (Assume that the critical angle of glass is \(42^\circ\)). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: Figure 6 shows a circuit comprising a coil, a bulb, a cell, and a milliammeter. It is observed that when the switch is closed, a current flows in the milliammeter. Explain this observation. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: A heater of resistance \(R_1\) is rated \(P\) watts, \(V\) volts while another of resistance \(R_2\) is rated \(2P\) watts, \(\frac{V}{2}\) volts. Determine \(\frac{R_1}{R_2}\). (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: An observer standing between two cliffs 680 m from one of them blows a whistle and hears the first echo after \(4.0 \, \text{s}\). He then moves 17 meters further away from the cliff and blows the whistle again. He now hears the echo after \(6.0 \, \text{s}\). Determine the speed of the sound. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text: An observer standing between two cliffs blows a whistle and hears two successive echoes from the cliffs after time intervals of \(2.0 \, \text{s}\) and \(3.0 \, \text{s}\). The observer then walks a distance of 170 m towards the cliff that produces the first echo and blows the whistle again. He now hears the two successive echoes after \(0.5 \, \text{s}\) and \(2.5 \, \text{s}\). Determine the distance between the cliffs. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 7 shows a simple electric bell circuit.
(i) Name the parts labelled:
I. D (1 mark)
II. E (1 mark)
(ii) When the switch is closed, the hammer hits the gong repeatedly. Explain why:
I. The hammer hits the gong. (2 marks)
II. The hammer hits the gong repeatedly. (2 marks)
(b) An electric bulb is rated 60 W, 240 V. Determine:
(i) The current that flows through it when it is connected to a 240 V supply. (2 marks)
(ii) The resistance of the bulb. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 8 shows two coils A and B placed close to each other. Coil A is connected to a battery and a switch while coil B is connected to a galvanometer. The secondary coil has 200 turns. The primary coil is connected to a 240 V alternating current (a.c.) mains supply.
(i) Explain how an e.m.f. is induced in the secondary coil. (2 marks)
(ii) Determine the secondary voltage. (2 marks)
(iii) Determine the efficiency of the transformer given that the current in the primary coil is \(0.20 \, \text{A}\) and in the secondary coil is \(0.80 \, \text{A}\). (3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 9 shows a circuit used to charge a capacitor.
(i) State the observation on the milliammeter when the circuit is switched on. (1 mark)
(ii) Explain the observation in (a)(i) above. (2 marks)
(b) The circuit in Figure 9 is left on for a duration of time. State the value of potential difference (p.d.) across:
(i) The resistor \(R\). (1 mark)
(ii) The capacitor \(C\). (1 mark)
(c) Sketch the graph of potential difference \(V\) across \(R\) against time. (1 mark)
(d) Figure 10 shows three capacitors connected to a 10 V battery. Calculate:
(i) The combined capacitance of the three capacitors. (3 marks)
(ii) The charge on the \(5.0 \, \mu\text{F}\) capacitor. (3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) When a radiation was released into a diffusion chamber, short thick tracks were observed. State with a reason, the type of radiation that was detected. (2 marks)
(b) The half-life of an element \(X\) is 3.3 days. A sample of this element is found to have an activity of \(10 \times 10^3\) disintegrations per second at a particular time. Determine its activity rate after 19.15 days. (3 marks)
(c) State what is meant by an extrinsic semi-conductor. (1 mark)
(d) Figure 11 shows a depletion layer in an unbiased p-n junction. State how a battery can be used to make the depletion layer narrower. (1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 12 shows an incomplete circuit of a full wave rectifier. Draw in the Figure 12 two more diodes to complete the circuit. (2 marks)
(b) Show on the Figure 12 the points across which the output of the rectifier should be obtained. (2 marks)
(c) An observer standing between two cliffs blows a whistle and hears two successive echoes. The observer then walks a distance towards one of the cliffs and blows the whistle again. The graph in Figure 13 shows the relation between the time interval, \(t\), and the distance, \(x\), from the centre.
(i) From the graph, determine the value of \(x\) for which the time interval was 0.55 seconds. (1 mark)
(ii) Given that \(t = \frac{4x}{v}\), where \(v\) is the speed of sound in air, determine the value of \(v\) from the graph. (3 marks)
(iii) If the maximum time measured by the observer was \(t = 4.75\), determine the distance \(l\) between the cliffs. (3 marks)
(d) A search boat uses a signal of frequency \(6.0 \times 10^2 \, \text{Hz}\) to detect a sunken ship directly below. Two reflected signals are received, one after 0.1 seconds from the sunken boat and the other after 0.14 seconds from the sea bed. If the sea bed is 90 m below the boat, determine:
(i) The speed of the signal in water. (3 marks)
(ii) The depth of the sunken ship below the boat. (2 marks)

fields.subject: Art
fields.text:
ALTERNATIVE A: DRAWING OR PAINTING
You are instructed that the use of rulers, tracing paper and other mechanical devices is forbidden in this alternative.
EITHER
DRAWING
1. Create an imaginative composition on the theme 'the first bicycle ride'.
The composition should be within an area of 35 cm by 45 cm.

fields.subject: Art
fields.text:
OR
PAINTING
2. Paint an imaginative composition of an elephant bathing its young one in a pool of muddy water.
The composition should be in an area of 35 cm by 45 cm.

fields.subject: Art
fields.text:
ALTERNATIVE B: GRAPHIC DESIGN
You are instructed that the use of rulers, tracing paper and other mechanical devices is allowed in this alternative. The colour of the working surface (paper) will not be considered as one of the colours required.
EITHER
3. Modella creations, a youth group fashion company dealing in African designs requires to market its merchandise.
In three colours design the following for the company:
(i) Carrier bag measuring 20 cm by 25 cm.
(ii) Compliment slip measuring 9.9 cm by 21 cm.
(iii) DVD case front panel insert measuring 12 cm by 12 cm.

fields.subject: Art
fields.text:
OR
4. Your time in high school is coming to an end, appreciate your Art and design teacher by;
Designing a beautiful personalised thank you card; showing the front and inside panels, each measuring 15 cm by 21 cm in four colours.

(b) Explain four rules to observe when removing stains from a garment.
(8 marks)
(c) Outline three remedies for each of the following machine faults:
(6 marks)
(i) Needle breaking
(ii) Fabric puckering

fields.subject: Home Science
fields.text:
(a) Describe the functioning of each of the following:
(4 marks)
(i) Electric Air fan
(ii) Air conditioner
(b) Explain four benefits of living in a well ventilated house.
(8 marks)
(c) Outline four ways in which cosmetics can be misused.
(8 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Evaluate 190.1 × 30, correct to 3 significant figures.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Find the sum of the first 10 terms in the Geometric Progression 3, 6, 12, ...
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Given that 5, \( x \), 35 and 84 are in proportion, find the value of \( x \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The base of a triangle is 3 cm longer than its height and its area is 35 cm². Determine the height and base of the triangle.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below is a map of a piece of land on a grid of 1 cm squares. Estimate the area of the map in square centimetres.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A chord of a circle, radius 5 cm, subtends an angle of 30° at the centre of the circle. Determine the length of the chord, correct to 2 decimal places.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The extension (E), in cm, of a rubber band when pulled by a force (F) was found experimentally and recorded as shown in the table below:
Force (F)02468
Extension (E) cm036912
(a) On the grid provided, draw a graph of extension(E) against force(F).
(2 marks)
(b) Use the graph to determine the extension when the force is 7 units.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The position of towns M and N are M(0°, 51°W) and N(0°, 37°E). Find the distance between the two towns in kilometres, correct to one decimal place. (Take the radius of the earth as 6370 km and \( \pi = \frac{22}{7} \)).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The table below shows the values of \( y = 2\sin(\theta + 30^\circ) \) for \( 0^\circ \leq \theta \leq 360^\circ \).
\( \theta \)0°30°60°90°120°150°180°210°240°270°300°330°360°
\( y = 2\sin(\theta + 30^\circ) \)11.721.710-1-1.7-2-1.7-101
(a) On the grid provided below, draw the graph of \( y = 2\sin(\theta + 30^\circ) \) for \( 0^\circ \leq \theta \leq 360^\circ \). Use 1 cm for 30° on the x-axis and 2 cm for one unit on the y-axis.
(3 marks)
(b) Use the graph to determine the value of y when \( \theta = 162^\circ \).
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below represents the distance covered by a car within a given period of time. Find the average speed of the car in kilometres per hour.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Kitonga deposited Ksh 50000 in a bank which paid compound interest at the rate of 10% per annum. Find the compound interest accrued by the end of the fourth year.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The number of different vehicles allowed through a road block was recorded as follows:
Type of vehiclesCarsLorriesPick-upsBusesTankers
No. of vehicles5935264713
Represent the above data in a pie chart.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Somi bought 2 pencils and 3 rubbers for Ksh 60 from a certain shop. Miheso bought 1 pencil and 2 rubbers for Ksh 35 from the same shop. Find the price of one pencil and that of one rubber.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) Find a matrix which, when multiplied by matrix \( M = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 2 \\ 7 & 5 \end{pmatrix} \) gives the identity matrix.
(2 marks)
(b) Given that \( N = \begin{pmatrix} x & 2 \\ 6 & 4 \end{pmatrix} \) is a singular matrix, find the value of x.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A square QRST with vertices Q(1,1), R(3,1), S(3,3) and T(1,3) is transformed by the matrix \( \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 1 \\ 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix} \) to Q'R'S'T'. Find:
(a) the area of square QRST;
(2 marks)
(b) the area of image Q'R'S'T'.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Given that \( \mathbf{p} = 6\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} \), determine the magnitude of p, correct to 2 decimal places.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The second term of an arithmetic progression(AP) and fourth term of a geometric progression(GP) are each 80. The sixth terms of the AP and GP are each 320.
(a) Find:
(i) the first term and the common differences of the AP.
(2 marks)
(ii) the first term and the common ratio of the GP.
(2 marks)
(b) Determine the 20th term of the AP.
(2 marks)
(c) Determine the difference between the sum of the first 12 terms of GP and the sum of the first 12 terms of the AP.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) (i) Complete the table below for the values of \( y = x^2 - 6x \) for -3 ≤ x ≤ 4.
x-3-2-101234
y = x² - 6x
(2 marks)
(ii) Find y when \( x = \frac{1}{2} \).
(1 mark)
(b) On the grid provided, draw a graph of \( y = x^2 - 6x \) for -3 ≤ x ≤ 4.
(3 marks)
(c) On the same grid, draw line \( y = -\frac{3}{2} x + 1 \) and hence solve the equation \( x^2 - 6x = -\frac{3}{2} x + 1 \).
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The marked price of a wall unit was Ksh 50 000. The price on hire purchase (HP) terms was 175% of the marked price.
(a) A customer bought the wall unit in cash and was offered 10% discount. Find the amount of money the customer paid for the wall unit.
(2 marks)
(b) A second customer decided to purchase a similar wall unit on HP terms.
(i) Determine the HP price.
(2 marks)
(ii) The customer paid 20% of the HP price as deposit and was to pay the balance in 28 equal monthly instalments. Find the amount of each monthly instalment.
(3 marks)
(c) A third customer bought a similar wall unit in cash by taking a loan equal to the marked price. The loan was to be repaid in 15 months and the bank charged interest at the rate of 4% compounded monthly.
(i) Find, correct to the nearest shilling, the amount of money the third customer paid the bank.
(2 marks)
(ii) Find the amount of money the third customer spent more than the marked price.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below shows triangle ABC in which AB = 6 cm, BC = 8 cm, BD = 4.2 cm and AD = 5.3 cm. Angle CBD = 45°.
Calculate, correct to one decimal place:
(a) the length of CD;
(3 marks)
(b) size of angle ABD;
(3 marks)
(c) size of angle BCD;
(2 marks)
(d) area of triangle ABD.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Mawira, a poultry farmer carried out the following transactions during the month of February 2017:
February 1: Had Ksh 10000 carried forward from January 2017
3: Bought 2 bags poultry feed @Ksh 1250
7: Paid Ksh 750 for water
11: Bought materials for construction for Ksh 1900
13: Received Ksh 12000 from sale of broilers
17: Sold 500 eggs at Ksh 8 each
21: Paid wages to 2 casuals at Ksh 1750 each
24: Sold chicks for Ksh 5000
25: Paid Ksh 1300 for electricity
26: Sold 30 layers at Ksh 500 each
28: Bought incubator for Ksh 12500
Prepare a single column cash book for Mawira's transactions and balance it as at 1st March 2017.
(10 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The table below shows the marks of 50 candidates in a test.
Marks1-1011-2021-3031-4041-5051-6061-7071-8081-9091-100
Frequency24581195321
(a) Draw a cumulative frequency curve for the data.
(5 marks)
(b) Use the graph to determine:
(i) the median mark;
(2 marks)
(ii) the percentage of students who scored above 64%.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Two boxes B and C contain identical balls except for the colour. Box B contains 5 violet balls and 3 green balls. Box C contains 3 violet balls and 4 green balls.
(a) A ball is drawn at random from each box. Find the probability that both balls are of the same colour.
(4 marks)
(b) Two balls were drawn at random from each box, one ball at a time without replacement. Find the probability that:
(i) the two balls drawn from box B or box C are violet;
(4 marks)
(ii) all the four balls drawn are violet.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The vertices of a triangle ABC are A(2, 2), B(5, 3) and C(3, 5).
(a) Find the vertices of Δ A'B'C', the image of Δ ABC under the transformation represented by the matrix \( \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 2 \\ 2 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \).
(2 marks)
(b) Triangle ABC is mapped onto Δ A''B''C'' whose vertices are A''(-2, 2), B''(-5, 3) and C''(-3, 5). Find the matrix of this transformation.
(4 marks)
(c) Triangle ABC undergoes two successive transformations PQ = \( \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 2 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \). Determine the vertices of Δ A'''B'''C''', the image of Δ ABC, under the combined transformation.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) Express 4732 in terms of its prime factors.
(1 mark)
(b) Find the smallest positive number that must be multiplied by 4732 to make it a perfect square.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Three people Juma, Weru and Njeri went round a circular racing track, 3.12 km long. They all started from the same point and moved in the same direction. Juma walked at 48 m per minute, Weru ran at 120 m per minute while Njeri cycled at 156 m per minute.
If they started travelling at 0700 h, find the time when they were first together again.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Evaluate \[ \frac{-9 + 3 \times 4 - 2}{(15 - 5) + 4} \]
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Without using a calculator, evaluate \[ \frac{\frac{3}{4} \cdot 8 \cdot \frac{1}{5} - \frac{4}{2}}{\frac{1}{4} + \frac{17}{8} \times \frac{3}{10}} \]
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Use logarithms to evaluate: \[ \frac{84.56 \sqrt[3]{0.0027}}{0.045} \] correct to 4 significant figures.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The diagram below represents a cube of side 10 cm from which a cuboid measuring \( x \) cm by \( x \) cm by 10 cm is removed as shown.
Write an expression in terms of \( x \), for the surface area of the remaining solid.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A cylindrical tank 1.4 m in diameter contains 3234 litres of water. Find the depth, in metres, of the water. (Take \(\pi = \frac{22}{7}\)).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below represents a quadrilateral ABCD in which angle DAB = 60°, angle BCD = 30° and BC = DC = 40 cm. Side AB = AD.
Calculate the area of the quadrilateral ABCD correct to 4 significant figures.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The area of a sector of a circle is 36.96 cm\(^2\). The sector subtends an angle of 135° at the centre of the circle. Find the radius of the circle. (Take \(\pi = \frac{22}{7}\)).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Evaluate the expression \[ \frac{r^2 + 3/r}{t - 3\frac{2}{3}} \] given that \( t = 5 \) and \( r = 27 \).
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Two employees Njoka and Okoth contributed \(\frac{1}{4}\) and \(\frac{1}{6}\) of their salaries respectively to start a project. The contribution amounted to Ksh 16 000. If Njoka contributed \(\frac{4}{9}\) and Okoth \(\frac{1}{3}\) of their salaries, the contribution would have been Ksh 30 000. Calculate each person's salary.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Solve \( x - 8 \leq -x \geq 4 - 3x \) and represent the integral values of \( x \) on a number line.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Figure ABCDEF is a regular hexagon. Line AE and BF intersect at G.
Find the size of angle FGE.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Using a ruler and a pair of compasses only, construct triangle PQR in which \( \text{PQ} = 8 \, \text{cm}, \angle \text{RPQ} = 60^\circ \) and \( \angle \text{PRQ} = 75^\circ \). Measure PR.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The marked price of a TV set is Ksh 36 000. A dealer sold the set and allowed a 12% discount on the marked price and still made a 25% profit on the cost price. Find the cost price of the set.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Figure A'B'C'D' is the image of ABCD under a rotation. By construction, determine the centre P and the angle of rotation.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A saleslady earns a monthly salary of Ksh 60 000. She gets a commission of 4% on the value of goods she sells above Ksh 250 000 but less than Ksh 400 000. On goods sold above Ksh 400 000, she gets a commission of 7.5%.
(a) In a certain month, she sold goods worth Ksh 525 000. Calculate her total earnings that month.
(4 marks)
(b) In another month, she earned a total of Ksh 94 500. Find the value of goods that she sold that month.
(6 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Lines \( y + 2x = 4 \) and \( 3x - y = 1 \) intersect at point T.
(a) Find the equation of line L, which passes through point T and (3,-2).
(5 marks)
(b) A line \( L_2 \) passes through (5,4) and is parallel to \( L_1 \). Find the equation of \( L_2 \) in the form \( y = mx + c \) where m and c are constants.
(2 marks)
(c) Another line \( L_3 \) is perpendicular to \( L_1 \) at T. Find the equation of \( L_3 \) in the form \( ax + by = c \) where a, b and c are integers.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A car travelled from town A to town B. The car started from rest at A and moved with a constant acceleration for 2 minutes and attained a speed of 1.2 km/minute. It then maintained this speed for a further 10 minutes before decelerating at a constant rate for another four minutes. The car finally came to rest at B.
(a) On the grid provided, draw a speed-time graph for the car.
(4 marks)
(b) Use the graph to calculate:
(i) the distance, in metres, the car travelled during its deceleration;
(2 marks)
(ii) the distance, in kilometres, covered by the car in the whole journey;
(2 marks)
(iii) the average speed, in km/h, for the whole journey.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below is a square of side \( x \) cm. The square is divided into four regions A, B, C and D. Regions A and C are squares. Square C is of side \( y \) cm. Regions B and D are rectangles.
(a) Find the total area of the following regions in terms of \( x \) and \( y \) in factorised form:
(i) A and C;
(1 mark)
(ii) B and D;
(2 marks)
(iii) A, B, C and D.
(2 marks)
(b) Find the total area of B and D in terms of x given that y = 2 cm.
(2 marks)
(c) Factorise 25c² - 16.
(1 mark)
(d) Evaluate without using mathematical tables:
(i) 5024² - 4976²
(1 mark)
(ii) 8.96² - 1.04²
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below represents a right pyramid VEFGH mounted on a cuboid ABCDEFGH. Line AB = 6cm, DA = 8cm and AF = BG = CH = DE = 3cm. Line VE = VF = VG = VH = 13cm.
Calculate, correct to 2 decimal places:
(a) the surface area of the rectangular faces;
(3 marks)
(b) the surface area of the triangular faces.
(5 marks)
(c) the total surface area of the solid.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The figure below is a solid which consists of a frustum of a cone, a cylinder and a hemispherical top. The internal radii of the frustum are 42 cm and 21 cm. The vertical height of the original cone was 40 cm and the height of the cylinder is 30 cm.
Calculate:
(a) the volume of the frustum part;
(5 marks)
(b) the volume of the cylindrical part;
(2 marks)
(c) the total volume of the solid.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Four posts A, B, C and D stand on a level horizontal ground. Post B is 240 m on a bearing of 060° from A, C is 210 m to the south of B and D is 150 m on a bearing of 140° from A.
(a) Using a scale of 1 cm to represent 30 m, show the relative positions of the posts.
(4 marks)
(b) Use the scale drawing to:
(i) find the distance and the bearing of C from D;
(2 marks)
(ii) determine how far A is to the west of B.
(2 marks)
(c) The height of post D is 18 m. Calculate, correct to 2 decimal places, the angle of elevation of the top of post D from the foot of post A.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The vertices of a triangle are A(-2, 2), B(2, 2) and C(2, 8).
(a) On the grid provided, draw triangle ABC and its image \(A'B'C'\) under a rotation of -90° about R(1,1).
(3 marks)
(b) The vertices of triangle \(A''B''C''\) are \(A''(-1, -5)\), \(B''(-1, -3)\) and \(C''(-4, -3)\).
(i) Draw triangle \(A''B''C''\).
(1 mark)
(ii) Describe fully the transformation X that maps \(\Delta A'B'C'\) onto \(\Delta A''B''C''\).
(3 marks)
(c) Triangle \(A'''B'''C'''\) is the image of triangle \(A''B''C''\) under a reflection in the line \(x = 0\). On the same grid, draw triangle \(A'''B'''C'''\).
(1 mark)
(d) State the type of congruence between:
(i) \(\Delta ABC\) and \(\Delta A'B'C'\).
(1 mark)
(ii) \(\Delta A''B''C''\) and \(\Delta A'''B'''C''\).
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
In order to determine the size of an oil molecule, a student performed an experiment using five oil drops to make a circular patch of the oil on the surface of water in a waterbath. State two assumptions made by the student during the calculations.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
In an experiment to determine the density of Liquid R, a student obtained the followed data:
- Mass of an empty density bottle = 55.0 g
- Mass of the density bottle + water = 80.0 g
- Mass of the density bottle + Liquid R = 70.0 g
Determine the density of Liquid R. (density of water is 1000 kgm\(^3\))
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
It is observed that when 20 cm\(^3\) of alcohol is mixed with 20 cm\(^3\) of water, the volume of the mixture is 39 cm\(^3\). State a reason why the volume of the mixture is not 40 cm\(^3\).
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
When a liquid is heated in a glass flask, it is observed that the level at first goes down and then rises. Explain this observation.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 1 shows a uniform wooden bar at equilibrium with two cans Y and Z of equal mass but different diameters.
The cans are simultaneously filled with equal volumes of water.
Explain the observation made.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State the reason why the speed of water at the narrow section of a river is higher than at the wider section.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A stone is thrown vertically upwards. Sketch a graph of potential energy (y axis) against time as the stone moves until it hits the ground.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Using the definition of impulsive force, show that \( F = ma \)
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 2 shows a round bottomed flask fitted with a long capillary tube containing a drop of coloured water.
The flask is immersed in ice water for sometime. State the observation made.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one assumption for the experiments carried out to verify the gas laws.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A student who wanted to take a bath mixed 4 kg of water at 80°C with 6 kg of water at 20°C. Determine the final temperature of the water.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A uniform metre rule is pivoted at its centre. Two weights of 20 N and 10 N are suspended at the 20 cm and 100 cm marks respectively. Determine the position at which a 10 N weight should be suspended in order to balance the system.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 3 shows two possible designs of a three legged stool.
State a reason why B is more stable than A.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) A tape attached to an accelerating trolley passes through a ticker timer that makes dots on it at a frequency of 50 Hz. The ticker timer makes 10 dots on a 10 cm long tape such that; the distance a between the first two dots is 0.5 cm and the distance b between the last two dots is 1.5 cm.
(i) Determine the velocity of the trolley at:
(I) distance a
(4 marks)
(II) distance b
(2 marks)
(ii) Determine the acceleration of the trolley.
(3 marks)
(b) State with a reason what would be observed on the spacing between the dots on the tape when the trolley is made to move on a horizontal surface.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) A student was provided with several identical masses, a metre rule, a spring and a stand, boss and clamp. Outline five steps that the student should follow in order to verify Hooke's law.
(5 marks)
(b) Figure 4 shows a graph that was drawn from the results obtained in an experiment to study the extension of a spring.
From the graph determine:
(i) The spring constant K
(3 marks)
(ii) The load that causes an extension of \( 3 \times 10^{-2} \, \text{m} \).
(1 mark)
(c) Three identical springs of spring constant 100 \(\text{Nm}^{-1}\) are arranged as shown in Figure 5 to support a 5N load.
Determine the total extension in the arrangement.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) In an experiment to determine the size of an oil molecule, oil is placed on the surface of water after sprinkling lycopodium powder on it.
(i) State two reasons why oil is used.
(2 marks)
(ii) State the function of the lycopodium powder.
(1 mark)
(iii) State any two assumptions that are made in this experiment.
(2 marks)
(iv) Explain why the oil spreads on the surface of water.
(2 marks)
(b) The following data was obtained from an experiment to determine the size of a palm oil molecule.
- Volume of 100 drops of palm oil = \( 15.0 \, \text{mm}^3 \)
- Area of a patch from one drop of oil = \( 8.0 \times 10^4 \, \text{mm}^2 \)
Determine the size of a palm oil molecule.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) State the law of flotation.
(1 mark)
(b) Figure 6 shows two solids W and X made of the same material and immersed in water.
(i) State with a reason which one of the containers experiences a greater upthrust.
(2 marks)
(ii) Solid W weighs 12N in air, 2N in water and 4N in another liquid. Determine the density of the other liquid.
(3 marks)
(c) Figure 7 shows two identical wooden blocks each of mass 0.2 kg suspended in water by two strings M and N.
Given that the upthrust on each block is 3.2N, determine the tension in string;
(i) M
(2 marks)
(ii) N
(2 marks)
(d) State any one application of hydrometers.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 8 shows part of a hydraulic brake system.
Describe how the systems works.
(5 marks)
(b) State three conditions necessary for a driver to negotiate a bend on a flat level road at a relatively high speed.
(3 marks)
(c) Figure 9 shows two identical cans U and V each with a small opening at the top. Different amounts of water were put into the cans and heated until the water started to boil.
Explain what will be observed when both cans are then suddenly dipped into a cold waterbath.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
Name four systems of poultry rearing.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
State three advantages of contemporary comparison method of selecting breeding stock.
(1½ marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
Give the meaning of the following terms as used in livestock breeding:
(a) close breeding
(½ mark)
(b) line breeding
(½ mark)
(c) out crossing
(½ mark)
(d) cross breeding
(½ mark)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
State four livestock rearing practices undertaken in a crush to control parasites and diseases.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
Name the dairy cattle breed that
(a) produces the highest milk yield in kilograms
(½ mark)
(b) is fawn/brown coloured with white colour on the face, legs below knees and hocks, tail switch and flanks
(½ mark)
(c) is most suitable for marginal areas with poor pastures.
(½ mark)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
Distinguish between each of the following breeding practices:
(a) crutching and ringing
(1 mark)
(b) tupping and serving
(1 mark)
(c) tupping and serving
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
What is a predisposing factor of a disease?
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
State four candling qualities of good eggs for incubation.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
Apart from the roof, name four other parts of a building that can be constructed using wood.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
State four symptoms of internal parasite infestation in livestock.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
State the functional difference between the following:
(a) cross-cut saw and rip saw
(1 mark)
(b) wood chisel and cold chisel
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
Give the meaning of the following terms as used in livestock health:
(a) predisposing factor
(1 mark)
(b) incubation period
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
The diagram below shows a livestock parasite.
(a) Identify the parasite.
(1 mark)
(b) Explain how the parasite is passed from
(i) livestock to human beings
(1 mark)
(ii) human beings to livestock
(1 mark)
(c) Explain two control measures for the parasite in a zero grazing unit.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Agriculture
fields.text:
The diagram below illustrates a tractor drawn implement.
(a) Identify the implement
(1 mark)
(b) Name the part labelled
H ......
(1 mark)

An experiment was carried out to investigate soil constituents as described below:
Step I – An empty evaporating dish was weighed and its mass was 10 gms.
Step II – Fresh garden soil was put on the evaporating dish and weighed. The mass was 40 gms.
Step III – The evaporating dish containing fresh soil was put in an oven and heated at a temperature of 105 °C for 30 minutes, cooled and then weighed. The mass was 35 gms.
Step IV – The dish containing soil was then strongly heated on a Bunsen burner for two hours while stirring. It was then cooled and weighed. The new mass was 32 gms.
(a) Give a reason why the soil was heated
(i) at 105°C
(1 mark)

(a) (i) Open a word processing program and key in the following text as it appears. Save the documents as socialnetwork.
(11 marks)
SOCIAL NETWORKING
Social networking platforms are used by organisation to improve communication and productivity by disseminating information among different groups of employees in a more efficient manner. The advantages and disadvantages of social media are as follows.
Advantages
• Facilities open communication.
• Allows employees to discuss ideas.
• Provides an opportunity to widen business contracts.
• Targets a wide audience.
• Improves business reputation and client base.
• Expands market research.
Disadvantages
☐ Susceptible to fraud
☐ Potentially results to hate speech
☐ Destructs normal business operations
Employers do have the right to ban computer activity that is not work related, this approach may not yield optimal results. If employees are to be allowed access to social networking platforms then a comprehensive and well defined policy should be established to prevent abuses.

Read the Poem below, and then an er the questions that follow.
A POISON TREE
I was angry with my friend: I told my wrath, my wrath did end. I was angry with my foe: I told it not, my wrath did grow.
And I watered it in fears, Night and morning with tears; And I sunned it with smiles, And with soft deceitful wiles.
And it grew both day and night. Till it bore an apple bright.
And my foe beheld it shine, And he knew that it was mine.
And into my garden stole, when the night had veiled the pole; in the morning glad I see;
My foe outstretched beneath the tree.
By William Blake

fields.subject: English
fields.text:
Read the passage below and then answer the questions that follow.
In life, we meet and learn from three different kinds of disciplines.
The first and probably the most important is that which we might call the Discipline of Nature or of Reality.
This type of discipline requires that when people choose to do the wrong things, they will get the wrong results.
If, for instance, a musician hits the wrong key, he or she hears the wrong note.
If the nail is not squarely hit on the head, it bends and it therefore has to be pulled out.
People meet the Discipline of Nature every time they try to do something.
This is why it is so important in school to give students more chances to do things, instead of just reading or listening to someone talk.
This discipline is a good teacher. The learner never has to wait long for the answer, it usually comes quickly, often instantly.
The answer is often clear, and it points towards the needed correction.
This way, the learner does not only see that what was done is wrong, but also why, and what they need to do instead.
Finally, and most importantly, the giver of the answer, call her 'Nature' is impersonal, impartial and indifferent.
She does not give opinions or make judgement. With Nature, one always gets an opportunity to start afresh, this time with the intention of doing things right.
The next type of discipline is the Discipline of Man is a social and cultural animal.
Everyone, thus, senses around them this discipline, this network of agreements, customs, habits and rules binding the society together.
People always seek to understand the society and be part of it.
They watch very carefully what other people around them are doing and wish to do the same.
These unwritten rules regarding how to act in specific situations are called social norms.
Social norms help delineate what is acceptable behaviour. For example, it is not acceptable to be loud and boisterous in a place of worship.
The third discipline is the one most people refer to when they speak of discipline - the Discipline of Superior Force.
It is the discipline of "You do what I tell you or I'll make you wish you had."
There is bound to be some of this in a person's life.
Living as we do surrounded by things that can hurt us and our friends, we cannot avoid the Discipline of Superior Force.
For example, no one can let a child find out from experience the danger of playing with fire.
So along with other precautions, the child is told not to play with fire or they will be punished.
There are situations where all the three disciplines overlap. We often hear people say that students will never do anything unless they are compelled to.
But in their private lives, or in co- curricular activities in school, they often submit themselves, willingly and wholeheartedly to very intense disciplines simply because they want to learn to do a given thing well.
So, discipline, does not only stem from authority figures such as parents and teachers but it also comes from a person's willingness to do right.
Adapted from Connelly Mark's The Brief Sundance Reader: Thomson Heinle, 2003
(a)
What are we told about the Discipline of Nature in the first paragraph?
(2 marks)
(b)
Identify and explain the use of personification in paragraph two.
(2 marks)
(c)
Why do you think the Discipline of Nature is said to be a good teacher?
(4 marks)
(d)

(2 marks)
(e)
"So, discipline does not only stem from authority figures such as parents and teachers but it also comes from a person's willingness to do right".
(Rewrite beginning: Not only...)
(1 mark)
(f)

(6 marks)
(g)

(3 marks)
(i)
Boisterous
(ii)
