fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Name three missionaries who came to Kenya before 1960. (3 marks)
(b) Discuss six results of the Maasai collaboration with the British in Kenya. (12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Identify three African nationalists who were imprisoned at Kapenguria in 1952. (3 marks)
(b) Discuss six political challenges experienced in Kenya between 1980 and 1999. (12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) State three roles of a Presiding Officer during a General election in Kenya. (3 marks)
(b) Discuss six functions of the Public Service in Kenya. (12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Give the composition of the Supreme Court of Kenya. (3 marks)
(b) Explain six functions of the High Court of Kenya. (12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Outline five principles of Public Finance in Kenya. (5 marks)
(b) Describe five ways in which the National Government of Kenya spends its revenue. (10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Identify two branches of History. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Give the current stage in the evolution of human beings. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Which was the first animal to be domesticated by the early human beings? (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: State two advantages of written messages as a form of communication. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Identify two factors that led to the decline of early urban centres in Africa. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Outline two uses of steel during the Industrial Revolution in Europe. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Give the main economic activity of the ancient City of Meroe. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Name one African community which participated in the Chimurenga War (1896-1897). (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: List two types of democracy. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Identify two methods used by the Europeans to acquire colonies in Africa. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Give one reason why the white settlers chose to establish self-government in Zimbabwe. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Name two military alliances which were formed during the Cold War. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Outline one reason why United States of America did not join the First World War until 1917. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Name the event that marked the end of the Second World War in 1945. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Identify the philosophy that was adopted by Tanzania for her development. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Define the term Commonwealth. (1 mark)

fields.subject: History
fields.text: Give two qualifications of a voter in Britain. (2 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Identify five animals domesticated in Mesopotamia during early agriculture. (5 marks)
(b) Discuss five effects of food shortage in Third World Countries. (10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) State five roles played by the Tuaregs during the Trans-Saharan trade. (5 marks)
(b) Explain five ways which were used to acquire slaves during the Trans-Atlantic trade. (10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Highlight five uses of gold in Africa during the pre-colonial period. (5 marks)
(b) Discuss five factors that led to the industrialization in Europe during the 19th Century. (10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) State five duties of the Lukilko among the Baganda during the pre-colonial period. (5 marks)
(b) Describe the social organization of the Shona in the 19th Century. (10 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Identify three organs of the Organization of African Unity (OAU). (3 marks)
(b) Discuss six challenges facing the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA). (12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Name three courts in the judicial system of India. (3 marks)
(b) Explain six functions of the Prime Minister of Britain. (12 marks)

fields.subject: History
fields.text:
(a) Outline three ways through which the United Nations promotes world peace. (3 marks)
(b) Discuss six political results of the First World War. (12 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Without using a calculator, evaluate \[ \frac{-13 + 5 - 70 + 5}{9 - 14 \times \frac{3}{4} + 21} \]
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Simplify the expression \[ \frac{3a^2 b^{-3}}{2^4 a^{-2} b^2} \]
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A triangle ABC is such that AB = 11 cm, BC = 8 cm and ∠ABC = 53°. Calculate the area of the triangle correct to 2 decimal places.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A cylindrical solid of radius 7 cm has a conical top of the same radius. The height of the cylindrical part of the solid is 17 cm. The conical top has a vertical height of 9 cm. Calculate the volume of the solid. \[ \left( \text{Take} \, \pi = \frac{22}{7} \right) \]
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Two light bulbs are set to light after every 40 seconds and 60 seconds respectively. If they light exactly at the same time initially, calculate:
(a) the time, in minutes, they will take to light together again.
(2 marks)
(b) the number of times they would light together in the first half an hour.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Solve the equation \( \cos 20 = \sin 0 \) for \( 0^\circ \leq 0 \leq \frac{\pi^\circ}{4} \). Leave the answer in terms of \( \pi^\circ \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Simplify and hence factorise the expression \( (5x - 4y) \ (4x + 5y) - 9xy \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
From a point on top of a cliff 40 m high, two boats A and B are observed due East. The angle of depression of boat A is 32° and that of boat B is 52°. Determine the distance between the two boats, correct to 2 decimal places.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In the following figure, triangle ABC is a uniform cross section of a solid ABCDEF. Given that BE is one of the edges of the solid, complete the sketch showing hidden edges with broken lines.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A salesman sells story books and textbooks. The cost price of a story book is sh 600 while that of a textbook is sh 900. The salesman is paid a commission of 10% on the cost of any book sold. One day, the salesman sold twice as many story books as textbooks. He earned a commission of sh 8 400. Determine the total number of story books sold.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The equation of a curve is given by \( y = x^2 \). Using the trapezium rule with 4 strips, estimate the area enclosed by the curve \( y = x^2 \), the lines \( x = 1 \), \( x = 5 \) and the \( x \)-axis.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Vectors a, b and c are represented on the following grid.
(a) the resultant vector \( \mathbf{a} + \mathbf{b} \)
(b) the resultant vector \( (\mathbf{a} + \mathbf{b}) + \mathbf{c} \)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Given matrix \( P = \begin{pmatrix} 4 & 2 \\ -7 & -1 \end{pmatrix}, Q = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 5 \\ 6 & -3 \end{pmatrix} \) and \( R = 20P^{-1} + Q \), determine matrix \( R \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In a sub county the number of children per family was recorded from 30 families. The data recorded is as follows:
2323414303
2213452763
6223335132
(a) Represent the data in a frequency distribution table.
(1 mark)
(b) Calculate the mean number of children per family.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text: The equation of a curve is given by \( y = 3x^2 - 2x \). Determine the equation of a normal curve at \( x = 2 \).

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
On the following cartesian plane provided, solve the simultaneous equations.
\[y = \frac{4}{3}x + 2\]
\[3y = x - 3\]

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Two towns, A and B are 400 km apart. A motor cyclist travelling at an average speed of 60 km/h left town A for town B at 1.20 p.m. A matatu travelling at an average speed of 80 km/h also left town A for town B at 2.00 p.m.
(a) Calculate, the:
(i) distance covered by the motor cyclist by 2.00 p.m.
(2 marks)
(ii) distance from town A in km, where the matatu caught up with the motor cyclist.
(3 marks)
(iii) time when the matatu caught up with the motor cyclist.
(2 marks)
(b) A lorry travelling at an average speed of 40 km/h left town B for town A at 2.00 p.m. Determine the time when the lorry and the matatu met.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
On the following grid, triangle PQR is drawn.
(a) On the same grid, draw:
(i) Triangle P'Q'R', the image of ΔPQR under a reflection in the line \( y = 0 \).
(2 marks)
(ii) Triangle P''Q''R'', the image of ΔP'Q'R' under an enlargement scale factor -1.5, centre O.
(3 marks)
(iii) Triangle P'''Q'''R''', the image of ΔP''Q''R'' under a half turn about O.
(2 marks)
(b) Describe a single transformation that maps ΔP'Q'R' onto ΔP'''Q'''R'''.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The following figure shows a right pyramid VABCD. The base ABCD of the pyramid is a square of side 8 cm. The length of the slanting edges \( VA = VB = VC = VD = 10 \) cm.
Calculate:
(a) the vertical height of the pyramid correct to 2 decimal places.
(4 marks)
(b) surface area of the pyramid.
(4 marks)
(c) the volume of the pyramid.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Neema went to the market to buy bananas worth Ksh 2 100 for a school. The seller offered a discount of Ksh 3 per banana which enabled Neema to buy 35 more bananas.
(a) Taking Ksh \( x \) as the price per banana before discount, write an expression for the:
(i) number of bananas that Neema would have bought before discount.
(1 mark)
(ii) actual number of bananas that Neema bought after the discount.
(1 mark)
(b) Form an equation in terms of \( x \) and hence determine the actual number of bananas Neema bought.
(6 marks)
(c) The bananas were given to students in a school. Two fifths of the students got 2 bananas each while the rest got a banana each. Determine the number of students in the school.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The end of term test scores of 100 students were recorded as shown in the following table.
Scores30 - 3940 - 4950 - 5960 - 6970 - 7980 - 89
No. of Students81028321210
(a) State the modal class.
(1 mark)
(b) Calculate the median score.
(3 marks)
(c) On the grid provided, represent the above data using a histogram.
(4 marks)
(d) Use the histogram to determine the number of students who scored from 71.5 to 76.5.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The following figure shows a quadrilateral PQRS and a circle passing through the vertices P, R and S. Lines PQ = PR = 2.7 cm, PS = 6 cm, SR = 7 cm and ∠PQR = 65°.
(a) Calculate:
(i) length QR.
(3 marks)
(ii) ∠PRS.
(3 marks)
(b) Determine the area of the circle.
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The displacement, \( x \) metres, of a particle moving a long straight line after \( t \) seconds is given by \( x = \frac{t^3}{3} - 3t^2 + 9 \).
(a) Determine:
(i) the values of \( t \) when the particle is momentarily at rest.
(3 marks)
(ii) the values of the displacement \( x \) metres by the time the particle comes to rest.
(2 marks)
(b) Determine the values of \( t \) when the velocity of the particle is \(-5 \, \text{m/s}\).
(3 marks)
(c) Determine the acceleration of the particle at \( t = 2 \) seconds.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In this question, use a ruler and a pair of compasses only. Line PR is a diagonal of a quadrilateral PQRS. PR = 6 cm.
(a) Locate vertex Q of the quadrilateral PQRS such that ∠ RPQ = 60° and ∠ PRQ = 45°. Complete triangle PQR and hence measure length PQ.
(4 marks)
(b) Diagonal QS, which is 10 cm long, intersects with diagonal PR at a right angle. Complete the quadrilateral PQRS.
(3 marks)
(c) Calculate the area of the quadrilateral PQRS.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Solve the equation \( 1 + \log(2x - 9) = \log(3x + 5) - \log 2 \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The masses of two students in a class were measured as 30.5 kg and 36.8 kg. Determine the least possible difference in the masses of the two students.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Make \( x \) the subject of the formula \( a = \frac{bx}{\sqrt{x^2 - 9}} \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In this question, use a ruler and a pair of compasses. The following figure shows a circle, centre O. A tangent to the circle at P is drawn. Construct another tangent to the circle to intersect the drawn tangent at an angle of 60°.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A plane took 3 hours to fly from P(66.42°N, 30°E) to Q(66.42°N, 52.5°E). Determine the speed of the plane in knots correct to one decimal place.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Solve \( 6 \cos^2 x = 5 \sin x \) for \( 0 \leq x \leq 180^\circ \).
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The following table shows the frequency distribution of marks scored by 40 students in a test.
Marks26 - 3031 - 3536 - 4041 - 4546 - 50
Frequency4101385
Calculate the upper quartile mark.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
Given that \( p = 5i - j + 3k, q = 8i + j \) and \( r = 2p - q \), determine the magnitude of \( r \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The following figure shows a circle centre O.
(a) Determine the equation of the circle.
(2 marks)
(b) Use the equation in part (a) to determine the \( x \)-intercept of the circle correct to 3 decimal places.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The following table shows monthly income tax rates of a certain year.
Monthly Income in Kenya Shillings (Ksh)Tax rate percentages (%) in each shilling
0 - 24 00010
24 001 - 32 33325
Above 32 33330
In that year, a monthly relief of Ksh 2 400 was allowed. The net tax on Lesianto's monthly income was Ksh 1 500. Calculate Lesianto's monthly income.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A transformation matrix \( T = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ k & 0 \end{pmatrix} \) maps \( P(2, 3) \) onto \( P'(2, 10) \). Point \( Q(-4, 4) \) is transformed under the same matrix \( T \). Find the coordinates of \( Q' \), the image of \( Q \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The length and width of a rectangular floor of a room are 10 m and 7 m respectively. A rectangular carpet of area 28 m\(^2\) is placed on the floor. The carpet leaves a uniform space of \( x \) m with each of the walls of the room. Form a quadratic equation in \( x \) and hence solve for \( x \).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A quantity v varies directly as the square of u and inversely as the cube root of w. When u = 5 and w = 8, the value of v = 375. Find the value of v when u = 8 and w = 125.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A stone was thrown upwards from a point 8 metres above the ground. The following graph shows the height, h metres of the stone above the ground at time t seconds in the interval \(0 \leq t \leq 4\). Determine the rate of change of h at \(t = 2\) seconds.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The gradient function of a curve is given by \(\frac{dy}{dx} = 3 - 4x\). If the curve passes through the point \((-1, 10)\), find the equation of the curve.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
P, Q and R are points on a level ground. Q is 4.5 m south of P. R is to the east of P and 5.3 m from Q. A vertical post at P is supported by a cable of length 3.5 m. The cable joins the top T of the post to point R. Calculate the angle between the cable and the level ground correct to 2 decimal places.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The first term of an arithmetic progression (A.P.) is \( a \) and the common difference \( d \). The 7th term of the A.P. is 11. The sum of the first 12 consecutive terms of the A.P. is 123.
(a) (i) Form two simplified equations involving \( a \) and \( d \) to represent the information.
(2 marks)
(ii) Find the values of \( a \) and \( d \).
(3 marks)
(b) The 1st, 3rd and 8th terms of the A.P. form the first 3 consecutive terms of a geometric progression (G.P.). Calculate:
(i) the 6th term of the G.P.
(3 marks)
(ii) the sum of the first 6 terms of the G.P.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
A welfare group invested Ksh 75 000 in shares and another Ksh 75 000 in a piece of land for a period of 5 years.
(a) Determine:
(i) the value of the shares at the end of the 5th year.
(4 marks)
(ii) the annual rate of appreciation in the value of the piece of land over the period of 5 years.
(3 marks)
(b) After the 5 year period, the shares depreciated in value at a rate of 3.5% p.a. for \( n \) years. The shares lost 10% of their value during this period. Determine the value of \( n \) correct to 2 decimal places.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) A number is selected at random from the numbers 90, 91, 92, 93 and 94. A second number is then selected at random from the numbers 2, 3, 4 and 5. Afterwards a quotient is obtained by dividing the first number selected by the second number.
(i) Complete the probability space in the following table.
+9091929394
246 \(\frac{1}{2}\)
330 \(\frac{2}{3}\)
422 \(\frac{3}{4}\)
518
(2 marks)
(ii) Determine the probability that the quotient obtained is a whole number.
(2 marks)
(iii) Determine the probability that the quotient obtained is a recurring decimal.
(1 mark)
(b) In a shooting practice the probability that a soldier will hit the target in his first attempt is 60%. This probability increases by 10% in the second attempt. The soldier shoots at the target twice. Determine the probability that:
(i) the soldier will miss the target only once.
(3 marks)
(ii) the soldier will miss the target in both attempts.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
(a) The table below shows values of \( x \) and some values of \( y \) for the curve \( y = 14 + 10x - 8x^2 - 4x^3 \). Complete the table.
x-2.5-2-1.5-1-0.500.511.5
y-600000000
(2 marks)
(b) On the grid provided, draw the graph of \( y = 14 + 10x - 8x^2 - 4x^3 \) for \( -2.5 \leq x \leq 1.5 \).
(3 marks)
(i) Use the graph to solve the equation \( 14 + 10x - 8x^2 - 4x^3 = 0 \).
(1 mark)
(ii) By drawing a suitable line graph on the same grid, solve the equation \( 4x^3 + 8x^2 - 5x - 4 = 0 \).
(4 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
An express train operates between two towns. The train pulls \( x \) coaches on first class and \( y \) coaches on economy class. Each first class coach can hold 72 passengers while each economy class coach can hold 120 passengers.
(a) Write down the inequalities that express the following conditions for a trip made by the train where the:
(i) total number of coaches used was less than 10.
(ii) train was pulling at least one first class coach.
(iii) number of economy class coaches was more than the number of first class coaches.
(iv) total number of passengers exceeded 360.
(b) Represent the inequalities in (a) on the grid provided.
(4 marks)
(c) The coaches for the trip were all fully booked. Each first class ticket costs Ksh 3000 while each economy class ticket costs Ksh 1000. Determine the maximum possible amount realised from the sale of tickets for the trip.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In this question, use a ruler and a pair of compasses only. The following figure is drawn to scale. It shows sides AB and AD of a trapezium ABCD in which AB and DC are parallel. Angle DAB = 40° and vertex C is not shown.
(a) On the figure, construct:
(i) the locus P of points equidistant from sides AB and AD.
(1 mark)
(ii) the locus Q of points equidistant from points A and B.
(1 mark)
(iii) the locus R of points such that \(\angle\) ARB = 70°.
(2 marks)
(b) Vertex C is such that \(\angle\) ACB = 70° Locate vertex C and hence complete the trapezium ABCD.
(3 marks)
(c) Calculate the area of trapezium ABCD.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
The following figure is a sketch of a curve whose equation is \( y = 3x^2 - 9x \). The curve cuts the \( x \)-axis at \( O(0, 0) \) and at \( R(3, 0) \). The curve cuts the line \( y = 12 \) at P and Q. The coordinates of Q is (4, 12). Line RN is perpendicular to PQ at N.
(a) Calculate:
(i) the area of the shaded region that lies below the \( x \)-axis.
(4 marks)
(ii) the area of the shaded region that lies to the right of line RN.
(4 marks)
(b) Hence calculate the total area of the shaded region.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Mathematics
fields.text:
In the following figure OABC is a trapezium. OA is parallel to CB and OA = 3 CB. M is the midpoint of AB.
(a) Given that OA = 3a and OC = c express in terms of a and c:
(i) AC
(1 mark)
(ii) AB
(2 marks)
(iii) OM
(2 marks)
(b) Lines AC and OM intersect at X such that OX = h OM and AX = k AC where h and k are scalars. Determine the values of h and k.
(5 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State with a reason the effect of reducing the heater current on the x-rays produced in an x-ray tube.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one property of a magnet.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State the importance of using the correct colour codes in the domestic wiring system.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Using the energy band theory, explain the difference between conductors and semi-conductors.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one quantity that must be kept constant for Ohm's law to hold.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 1 shows an object placed near the eye of a long sighted person. Complete the diagram to show where the image is formed.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 2 shows a student using a small plane mirror to view her image. Explain why the student is able to see her face but not her legs in the mirror.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 3 shows a coil made from tungsten being used to heat some water in a beaker at a constant voltage. State two ways in which the coil can be improved so that the water boils in a shorter time.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Describe how a cathode ray oscilloscope may be used to measure the voltage of an alternating signal.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Explain why it is not advisable to leave a lead acid accumulator in the discharge condition for a long time.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State two properties that distinguish electromagnetic waves from mechanical waves.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Thorium element decayed to produce gamma radiation as shown in the equation below: \[ \frac{a}{90} \text{Th} \rightarrow \frac{230}{b} \text{Th} + \gamma \]. State the values of a and b.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A student observed a rainbow when it was raining and the sun was shining. Explain how dispersion of white light by rain drops leads to the formation of the rainbow.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State the reason why sound waves get refracted away from the ground on a hot day.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 4 shows a gold-leaf electroscope.
(i) Identify the part labelled A.
(1 mark)
(ii) State the function of the parts labelled:
I. B
(1 mark)
II. C
(1 mark)
(b) A highly negatively charged rod is slowly brought close to a lightly positively charged gold leaf electroscope.
(i) State what is observed on the gold leaf.
(1 mark)
(ii) Explain the observation made in b(i).
(2 marks)
(c) Figure 5 shows a thin wire connected to a highly positively charged rod and placed close to a candle flame.
(i) State what is observed on the flame when the wire is brought closer.
(1 mark)
(ii) Explain the reason for the observation in c(i).
(1 mark)
(d) Figure 6 shows an arrangement of three capacitors in a circuit. Determine the effective capacitance of the arrangement.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) State Fleming's left hand rule.
(1 mark)
(b) Figure 7 shows an electric motor with a coil ABCD in the magnetic field.
(i) Indicate with an arrow on the coil ABCD, the direction of the current I when switch S is closed.
(1 mark)
(ii) State the direction in which the coil rotates when the switch is closed.
(1 mark)
(iii) Explain what makes the coil to rotate.
(3 marks)
(iv) State three ways in which the power of this motor can be increased.
(3 marks)
(v) State the purpose of the rheostat in the setup.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 8 shows a setup that may be used to investigate photoelectric effect. In the setup, a UV source is placed close to the window.
(i) Explain what is observed on the galvanometer when the window is opened and the switch is closed.
(3 marks)
(ii) Explain why parts A and B are placed in a vacuum.
(2 marks)
(b) A photon of red light has a wavelength of \(8.0 \times 10^{-1}\) m. Determine the energy it contains. (Planks constant h is \(6.63 \times 10^{34}\) Js and the speed of light c is \(3.0 \times 10^8\) ms\(^{-1}\)).
(3 marks)
(c) A metal surface has a work function of 4.5 eV. (Planks constant h is \(6.63 \times 10^{-34}\) Js and the electronic charge e is \(1.6 \times 10^{-19}\) C). Determine the:
(i) work function of the metal in joules (J).
(2 marks)
(ii) maximum wavelength of a radiation that will cause electrons to be emitted from the surface.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 9 shows the image produced by a concave mirror of focal length 20 cm.
(i) On the same diagram draw rays to show the position of the object.
(3 marks)
(ii) Given that the diagram is drawn to scale, determine the:
I. distance of the object from the mirror;
(1 mark)
II. magnification.
(3 marks)
(b) Figure 10 shows a ray of light incident at the pole of a convex mirror.
(i) Complete the diagram to show how the ray may be used to locate the image formed by the mirror.
(2 marks)
(ii) State any two characteristics of the image formed.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) A cliff obstructs an observer from seeing an approaching car. Explain how the sound from the car reaches the observer before the car emerges.
(2 marks)
(b) Figure 11 shows a displacement - time graph for a certain wave motion.
(i) Determine the:
I. period T;
(1 mark)
II. frequency f.
(2 marks)
(ii) On the same axis draw a wave whose frequency is twice the one obtained in part (II).
(2 marks)
(c) (i) State the meaning of the term "refraction".
(1 mark)
(ii) Figure 12, shows a rectangular glass block, dipped in a ripple tank in which plane water waves are generated. Complete the diagram to show how the water waves move in the region that has the glass block.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one way in which Physics contributes to the study of History.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
It is observed that diffusion is faster in gases than in liquids. State the reason for this observation.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A boarding school has two identical tanks A and B filled with water. All the surfaces of tank A are painted silvery shiny while the surfaces of tank B are painted black. It is observed that, for bathing in the morning, most of the students prefer fetching water from one particular tank.
(a) Identify the tank preferred by the students in the morning.
(1 mark)
(b) Explain why students prefer to use water in the tank identified in 3(a).
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 1 shows a uniform metre rule of negligible weight pivoted at the 40 cm mark. It is kept at equilibrium by a spring balance attached at the 100 cm mark and force F at the 60 cm mark. The reading on the spring balance is 1 N. Determine the value of F.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A mass of 40 g is suspended from a spring causing it to stretch. When a 20 g mass is added to it, the spring stretches further by 1.6 cm. Determine the spring constant. (gravitational field strength \( g = 10 \, \text{Nkg}^{-1} \))
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 2 shows a test tube containing air and fitted with a sliding cork. The tube is suspended horizontally by a thread. When the test tube was heated slightly, the cork moved and the tube tilted.
(a) State the direction in which the tube tilted.
(1 mark)
(b) Explain why the tube tilted as in 6(a).
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 3 shows two identical tennis balls K and L moving in air. Ball K spins as it moves while ball L does not. It is observed that ball K falls down faster than ball L. Explain this observation.
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 4 shows a velocity - time graph of a certain object. Describe the motion of the object.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
Figure 5 shows a toy car of mass 250 g moving from rest on a curved frictionless bowl of height 0.2 m. Determine the maximum kinetic energy that the toy attains. (gravitational acceleration \( g \) is 10 ms\(^2\)).
(3 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one factor that determines the speed at which a car negotiates a level circular path.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
A student observed that a burn by steam from boiling water was more severe than a burn by the boiling water. State the reason for this observation.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one advantage of a force pump over a lift pump.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
State one possible source of error that may occur when carrying out an experiment to verify Charles' Law.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) State two properties of alcohol that make an alcohol thermometer more suitable than a mercury-in-glass thermometer in measuring temperature.
(2 marks)
(b) Figure 6 shows Six's maximum and minimum thermometer.
(i) State the purpose of the:
I. part labelled X;
(1 mark)
II. mercury.
(1 mark)
(ii) State the reason why indices A and B are made of steel.
(1 mark)
(iii) Explain how the maximum temperature for a given day is determined using this type of thermometer.
(3 marks)
(iv) State the reason for the shape of the meniscus of mercury in Figure 6.
(1 mark)
(c) Figure 7 show a cork stuck in the neck of glass bottle. Explain how the cork can be removed from the bottle without breaking the bottle or the cork.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Explain the following observations using Newton's first law of motion:
(i) A trolley moving on a bench in a straight line eventually comes to rest;
(2 marks)
(ii) A passenger is jerked forward when a vehicle is suddenly stopped.
(2 marks)
(b) Figure 8 shows a graph of velocity against time for two identical ball bearings dropped into water and glycerine. State with a reason which of the two curves \( x \) or \( y \) shows the velocity of the ball bearing falling through water.
(3 marks)
(c) Figure 9 shows a student of mass 60 kg standing on a weighing balance calibrated in newtons in a lift. The lift is accelerating upwards at 0.25 ms\(^2\). Determine the reading on the weighing balance.
(3 marks)
(d) State one way of reducing frictional force experienced by an object sliding on a flat surface.
(1 mark)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 10 (a) shows two similar bottles P and Q of the same weight while Figure 10 (b) shows bottle P kept afloat in water using an inflated balloon. Bottle P in Figure 10 (b) is then replaced with bottle Q in Figure 10 (a).
(i) State what is observed on bottle Q.
(1 mark)
(ii) Explain the observation in part (i).
(2 marks)
(b) A piece of metal weighs 0.6 N in air and 0.5 N when fully submerged in water. When the metal is fully submerged in liquid L, it weighs 0.54 N. Determine the:
(i) relative density of the metal.
(3 marks)
(ii) relative density of liquid L.
(3 marks)
(iii) density of liquid L.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) In an experiment to estimate the diameter of an oil molecule, an oil drop of volume 6.55 × \(10^{-5}\) cm\(^3\) was placed on the surface of water. The oil spread to form a circular patch of diameter 8 cm.
(i) Determine the:
I. area of the oil patch;
(2 marks)
II. diameter of the oil molecule.
(3 marks)
(ii) State two assumptions made in such an experiment.
(2 marks)
(iii) State any two possible sources of error in the experiment.
(2 marks)
(b) Describe how the experiment in 17(a) could be used to determine the extent of accidental oil spillage in the sea.
(2 marks)

fields.subject: Physics
fields.text:
(a) Figure 11 shows two liquids L and M each of mass 1 kg in identical containers. Liquid L has higher heat capacity than liquid M. The liquids are heated with the same amount of heat for the same length of time.
(i) State the observation made on the readings of the two thermometers.
(1 mark)
(ii) Explain the observation in part (i).
(2 marks)
(iii) State two ways in which heat losses in the two calorimeters can be minimized.
(2 marks)
(b) A block of ice at 0 °C and of mass 5 g is placed into a calorimeter containing 50 g of water at 25 °C. If all the ice melted, determine the final temperature of the mixture. (Assume that negligible heat is absorbed by the calorimeter). Take the specific heat capacity of water as \(4200 \, \text{Jkg}^{-1} \, \text{k}^{-1}\) and the specific latent heat of fusion of ice as \(3.5 \times 10^5 \, \text{Jkg}^{-1}\).
(4 marks)
(c) It is observed that food cooks faster in a covered container than in an open container. Explain this observation.
(2 marks)
